stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on Course 15, spending most of the stream on a frustrating, deep-dive debugging session to fix an emulator-specific crash related to a snow effect. He also implemented and balanced tilting platforms, discussed performance optimizations, and collaborated with artist Biobak on redesigning the level's problematic background and 'styrofoam' ground texture.

development_findings.summary: A significant portion of the stream was dedicated to debugging a crash that only occurred on the Project64 emulator, not on other emulators or real N64 hardware, highlighting the challenges of developing for inconsistent emulation environments.
development_findings.quote: The worst problem is that on real n64 it legit just works.

development_findings.summary: Kaze eventually fixed the persistent emulator crash by changing a function from inline to non-inline, a workaround that points to a likely bug within the emulator's handling of compiled code rather than an error in the game's logic.
development_findings.quote: How does changing the function from an inline to not an inline make it work? This garbage emulator man I swear.

development_findings.summary: Course 15 suffers from major performance issues, primarily high RDP (Reality Display Processor) time caused by overdraw. Kaze plans to optimize it by cutting holes in the level geometry beneath other objects.
development_findings.quote: This is the worst performing level by far right now... My game thread is like twelve milliseconds, but then rendering takes forty. It's all RDP.

development_findings.summary: Kaze demonstrated the power of his custom engine optimizations by porting Super Mario Sunshine's Isle Delfino map, which ran at a stable 30 FPS on N64 hardware, a significant performance feat.
development_findings.quote: I just ported this to my current engine... Easy 30 fps on N64. Since then I made the game like twice as fast again.

development_findings.summary: Kaze notes that the game's new, more consistent physics engine makes platforming challenges inherently easier than in the original Super Mario 64, a factor he must consider when designing level difficulty.
development_findings.quote: With return to Yoshi's Island, the physics are so much more consistent that everything is easier in that sense.

development_findings.summary: Following feedback from Biobak and his own dissatisfaction, Kaze decided to replace the complex and buggy normal-mapped 'styrofoam' ground texture with a new concept: sheets of paper stapled to cardboard.
development_findings.quote: We need a different solution for the styrofoam then. What do we do if not styrofoam?

development_findings.summary: The game includes a built-in widescreen mode that properly increases the horizontal field of view rather than stretching the 4:3 image, offering a modern feature on original hardware.
development_findings.quote: If you're on a white screen tv you can just turn this on and you actually get a bigger field of view.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is using advanced, custom techniques to simulate normal mapping on the N64 by using two different texture formats and performing lighting calculations manually to store in a palette.
development_findings.quote: I made a ci4 texture with a grayscale palette and then I also made a ci4 texture with an RGBA16 palette to read it as a normal map and then I multiply them with the camera and like that and the light direction.

context_findings.summary: Kaze views making YouTube videos as a necessary chore to fund his passion for game development, which is his primary motivation.
context_findings.quote: I just want to make games, man.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is aware of the legal issues with Nintendo and acknowledges that any commercial release would require replacing all proprietary assets, making the game an original IP.
context_findings.quote: If I were to release this game on Steam, obviously I would have to remove all the Mario assets though.

context_findings.summary: Kaze jokes about marketing the game as a 'quadruple A' title, reflecting his pride in the significant technical and creative effort invested.
context_findings.quote: I'm going to say this is the first quadruple A N64 game ever. That's going to be the marketing.

context_findings.summary: Kaze often works at the absolute limit of the N64's hardware and his custom toolchain, where pushing visuals further can cause compilers to break or values to overflow.
context_findings.quote: The problem is I can't make it more shiny without the breaking. Like that's literally the most shiny I can make it before my compiler breaks down and the values overflow into weird colors that make no sense.

context_findings.summary: Kaze operates with a 'last impact mindset,' justifying the implementation of complex features he finds personally interesting, provided they don't negatively affect gameplay.
context_findings.quote: It is cool and I think as long as it's a gameplay it's fine for me to make things just because I want to.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration with repeated questions about the game's release date, indicating pressure from the community.
context_findings.quote: I will literally lose my mind. Please stop asking me for release dates.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided critical design feedback, questioning the aesthetic value of the complex 'styrofoam' normal map effect, which prompted Kaze to consider alternatives.
biobak.quote: Do we even want the normal map styrofoam? Do we think it looks good? I don't think it does.

biobak.summary: Biobak proposed a new visual concept for the level's background void, suggesting a gradient of darkening blue layers to create a death plane. Kaze received the idea positively and planned to implement it.

badub.summary: Badub, the composer, was not mentioned or involved in the activities of this stream.

zeina.summary: Zeina's friend, who is skilled with hardware, installed the N64 Digital HDMI mod on Kaze's console.
Zeina was mentioned briefly in a personal context, with Kaze joking about a potential Halloween costume involving them.

key_stories.title: The Emulator-Specific Crash
key_stories.summary: Kaze spent a large portion of the stream hunting a frustrating bug that only crashed the game on the Project64 emulator. After a long and arduous process of elimination that involved checking memory, assembly, and running on real hardware, he found a strange workaround, blaming the 'garbage emulator' for the issue.
key_stories.challenge: A persistent, elusive crash occurred in Course 15, but only on the Project64 emulator, making it extremely difficult to debug as it worked perfectly on real N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Kaze systematically investigated the crash, suspecting memory corruption from the 'styrofoam' effect. He used a debugger, examined the assembly code, tried different emulators, and ran the game on a real N64 to confirm the issue was emulator-specific. His frustration grew as his code seemed logically correct.
key_stories.outcome: After hours of debugging, Kaze discovered a bizarre workaround: changing a single function from 'inline' to a standard function call fixed the issue. He concluded the problem was a bug within Project64 itself, not his code, and was able to move on.
key_stories.key_quote: The whole time my code worked. The whole time I tried to fix my code it worked. It's just something else randomly started breaking again. That sucks.

key_stories.title: Replacing the Styrofoam
key_stories.summary: The team re-evaluated a complex 'styrofoam' ground effect that was buggy and aesthetically questionable. After a direct consultation with Biobak on stream, Kaze decided to scrap the effect in favor of a new concept of paper stapled to cardboard, better fitting the game's arts-and-crafts theme.
key_stories.challenge: The ground texture in Course 15, a complex normal-mapped 'styrofoam,' was causing bugs, didn't look good, and its value was questioned by the team.
key_stories.process: Kaze was struggling with bugs related to the styrofoam effect. He paused to ask his artist, Biobak, for an opinion. Biobak agreed it didn't look good, which validated Kaze's own feelings and led to a collaborative decision to replace it with a simpler, more creative 'crafts' solution.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to discard the styrofoam effect. The team settled on a new, more theme-appropriate idea: replacing the styrofoam with sheets of white paper stapled onto the cardboard ground.
key_stories.key_quote: Biobak, do we even want the normal map styrofoam? Do we think it looks good? I don't think it does.

key_stories.title: Redesigning the Level's Background
key_stories.summary: The main outdoor level had a poorly performing and ugly background. After dismissing his own ideas, Kaze received a concept from Biobak for a layered blue void. Kaze approved of the idea and planned to implement it while also doing major performance optimizations.
key_stories.challenge: The background of Course 15, an 'ocean' texture, performed poorly and was thematically confusing to players.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified the level's poor performance and ugly background as key issues. He considered several alternatives like a white void or a table but found them lacking. Artist Biobak then provided a visual mock-up of a layered blue void, which Kaze immediately liked and adopted as the new direction.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to implement Biobak's suggestion for a new background: a layered void that transitions from bright to dark blue, creating a clear death plane. He also planned to aggressively optimize the level by cutting holes in the geometry.
key_stories.key_quote: I also really want to prevent the player thinking that they can jump down and see something down there. That's one of my big worries, right?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions a 'zipper to hell' that will be added to Course 15, but provides no further details on what this entails.
questions: What was the design process behind this feature?
What gameplay function does it serve in the level?

open_questions.context: Kaze states that Biobak is there to make maps 'prettier' and sometimes finds optimizations, but that his changes can also make things 'more expensive'.
questions: Can you describe the typical workflow between you and Biobak when it comes to level art and optimization?
How do you balance Biobak's artistic enhancements with the N64's strict performance limitations?
Can you give an example of a time Biobak's change made a level more expensive, and how you two worked to solve it?

open_questions.context: Kaze spent hours debugging an issue specific to the Project64 emulator, and mentioned other emulators like Parallel Launcher are also problematic. The game is confirmed to work on real hardware.
questions: Given the severe emulator compatibility issues, what is your strategy for release and player support?
Will you officially recommend a specific emulator and configuration?
How much of a concern is it that a large portion of the potential audience uses these buggy emulators?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions that he could release the game on PC/Steam if he removed all the Mario assets.
questions: How seriously have you considered an original IP release on PC?
What would be the biggest challenges in transforming the game from a fan project into a commercial one, beyond swapping assets?
How much of the original design is tied to the Mario IP versus your own original ideas?

open_questions.context: Kaze showed off his impressive engine optimizations by running an imported Isle Delfino map at 30 FPS, mentioning it's the result of 3 years of work and makes the game '10 times the performance of normal vanilla Mario 64'.
questions: You mentioned a potential hour-long video on all your source code optimizations. Could you walk us through the top 3 most impactful optimizations you've developed?
What was the single biggest 'breakthrough' moment in optimizing the engine?
How has this highly optimized engine changed what you thought was possible on the N64?
